{{short description|Wikipedia list article}} {{Infobox former monarchy | royal_title = Grand Duke | realm = Tuscany | border = | coatofarms = Great_coat_of_arms_of_the_Grand_Duchy_of_Tuscany.svg | coatofarmssize = | coatofarmscaption = | image = Leopold II of Tuscany.jpg | caption = | first_monarch = [[Cosimo I de' Medici, Grand Duke of Tuscany]] | last_monarch = [[Leopold II, Grand Duke of Tuscany|Leopold II]] (de jure)
[[Ferdinand IV, Grand Duke of Tuscany|Ferdinand IV]] (de facto/titular) | style = [[Imperial and Royal Highness|His/her Imperial and Royal Highness]] | residence = | appointer = | began = 27 August 1569 | ended = 16 August 1859 | pretender = [[Archduke Sigismund, Grand Duke of Tuscany]] }} The '''rulers of [[Tuscany]]''' have varied over time, sometimes being [[margrave]]s, the rulers of handfuls of border counties and sometimes the heads of the most important family of the region. ==[[March of Tuscany|Margraves of Tuscany]], 812–1197== ===House of Boniface=== :These were originally counts of [[Lucca]] who extended their power over the neighbouring counties. *[[Boniface I of Tuscany|Boniface I]], 812–813 *[[Boniface II of Tuscany|Boniface II]], 828–834 *[[Aganus of Tuscany|Aganus]], 835–845 *[[Adalbert I of Tuscany|Adalbert I]], 847–886 *[[Adalbert II of Tuscany|Adalbert II the Rich]], 886–915 *[[Guy of Tuscany|Guy]], 915–929 *[[Lambert of Tuscany|Lambert]], 929–931 ===House of Boso=== :These were the (mostly illegitimate) relatives of [[Hugh of Arles]], [[King of Italy]], whom he appointed to their post after removing the dynasty of Boniface *[[Boso of Tuscany|Boso]], 931–936 *[[Humbert of Tuscany|Humbert]], 936–961 *[[Hugh of Tuscany|Hugh the Great]], 961–1001 ===House of Hucpold=== *[[Boniface, Count of Bologna|Boniface (III)]], 1004–1011 ===Nondynastic=== *[[Rainier of Tuscany|Rainier]], 1014–1027 ===[[Counts of Canossa|House of Canossa]]=== :These were the descendants of the [[Counts of Canossa]]. *[[Boniface III of Tuscany|Boniface III]], 1027–1052 *[[Frederick of Tuscany|Frederick]], 1052–1055 *[[Matilda of Tuscany|Matilda]], 1052–1115 **[[Beatrice of Bar]], 1052–1055 (regent as mother of Frederick and Mathilda) **[[Godfrey III, Duke of Lower Lorraine|Godfrey the Bearded, Duke of Lower Lorraine]], 1053–1069 (regent as husband of Beatrice and step-father to Frederick and Matilda) **[[Godfrey IV, Duke of Lower Lorraine|Godfrey the Hunchback, Duke of Lower Lorraine]], 1069–1076 (regent as husband of Matilda) **[[Welf II, Duke of Bavaria|Welf II]], 1089–1095 (co-regent as husband of Matilda) ===Nondynastic=== *[[Rabodo]], 1116–1119 *[[Conrad of Tuscany|Conrad]], 1119/20–1129/31 *Rampret, c. 1131 *[[Engelbert III of Sponheim|Engelbert]], 1134/5–1137 *[[Henry X, Duke of Bavaria|Henry the Proud]], 1137–1139 *[[Ulrich of Attems]], 1139–1152 (imperial vicar) *[[Welf VI]], 1152–1160 *[[Welf VII]], 1160–1167 **[[Rainald of Dassel|Rainald of Dassel, Archbishop of Cologne]], 1160–1163 (imperial vicar) **[[Christian, Archbishop of Mainz|Christian of Buch, Archbishop of Mainz]] 1163–1173 (imperial vicar) *[[Welf VI]], 1167–1173 *[[Philip of Swabia|Philip]], 1195–1197 ::In 1197 Philip was elected King of Germany and the majority of the Tuscan nobility, cities and bishops formed the [[Tuscan League]] with Papal backing. *[[Frederick of Antioch]], 1246–50 (imperial vicar) After this, Tuscany was splintered between the competing republics of [[Republic of Florence|Florence]], [[Republic of Pisa|Pisa]], [[Republic of Siena|Siena]], [[Arezzo]], [[Pistoia]] and [[Republic of Lucca|Lucca]]. Since the 14th century, Florence gained dominance over Pistoia (1306, officially annexed 1530), Arezzo (1384), Pisa (1406), and Siena (1559). Lucca was an independent republic until the [[Napoleonic]] period in the 19th century. ==Rulers of Florence, 1434–1569== ===De facto rulers of the [[Medici|House of Medici]], 1434–1494=== {| class="wikitable" |- ! Portrait !! Name !! From !! To !! Note |- | [[File:Cosimo de medici.png|75px]] || [[Cosimo de' Medici]] || 1434 || 1464 || First ''de facto'' Lord of Florence |- | [[File:Piero di Cosimo de' Medici.jpg|75px]] || [[Piero I de' Medici|Piero I the Gouty]] || 1464 || 1469 || Son of Cosimo |- | [[File: Lorenzo de Medici.jpg|75px]] || [[Lorenzo I de' Medici|Lorenzo I the Magnificent]] || 1469 || 1492 || Son of Piero |- | [[File:Giuliano de' Medici by Sandro Botticelli.jpeg|75px]] || [[Giuliano di Piero de' Medici|Giuliano I de' Medici]] || 1469 || 1478 || Brother of Lorenzo and also Co-Ruler, was assassinated. |- | [[File:501 Piero de Medici 02.JPG|75px]] || [[Piero II de' Medici|Piero II the Unfortunate]] || 1492 || 1494 || Son of Lorenzo, was deposed and exiled |} ==== Republic of Florence (1494-1512) ==== {| class="wikitable" |- ! Portrait !! Name !! From !! To !! Note |- | [[File:Girolamo Savonarola.jpg|75px]] || [[Girolamo Savonarola]] || 1494 || 1498 || Inspired reform around [[Florence]], was condemned a heretic and hanged and simultaneously burned at the stake in the middle of the piazza. |- | [[File:Piero Soderini (1450-1522), by Ridolfo del Ghirlandaio.jpg|75px]] || [[Piero Soderini]] || 1502 || 1512 || was declared ''Standard Bearer'' for life, fled Florence after the Medici conquest. |} ==== Rulers of the [[Medici|House of Medici]] (1512-1532) ==== {| class="wikitable" |- ! Portrait !! Name !! From !! To !! Note |- | [[File:Raffael 040 (crop).jpg|75px]] || [[Pope Leo X|Cardinal Giovanni de' Medici]] || 1512 ||1513 || Son of Lorenzo, later became '''Pope Leo X''' |- | [[File:Raffaello, giuliano de' medici.jpg|75px]] || [[Giuliano de' Medici, Duke of Nemours|Giuliano II, Duke of Nemours]] || 1513 || 1516 || Son of Lorenzo |- |[[File:Portrait of Lorenzo di Medici.jpg|75px]] || [[Lorenzo de' Medici, Duke of Urbino|Lorenzo II de Medici]] || 1516 || 1519 || Son of Piero the Unfortunate. [[Duke of Urbino]] during the same period. |- | [[File:Sebastiano del Piombo (Italian) - Pope Clement VII - Google Art Project.jpg|75px]] || [[Pope Clement VII|Cardinal Giulio de' Medici]] || 1519 || 1523 || son of [[Giuliano de Medici]], later became '''Pope Clement VII''' |- | [[File:Ippolito de' Medici.jpg|75px]] || [[Ippolito de' Medici]] || 1523 || 1527 || Son of Giuliano de Medici |- | [[File:Jacopo Pontormo 056.jpg|75px]] || [[Alessandro de' Medici]] || 1527 || 1530 || son of Lorenzo II de Medici, ruled in exile, returned and became Duke of Florence, where he was assassinated. |} After the [[Sack of Rome (1527)|Sack of Rome]], Florence overthrew the [[Medicis]] once more and became a republic until [[Pope Clement VII]] signed a peace treaty with [[Charles V, Holy Roman Emperor]] who then invaded Florence and restored the Medicis. {| class="wikitable" |- ! Portrait !! Name !! From !! To !! Note |- | [[File:Jacopo Pontormo 056.jpg|75px]] || [[Alessandro de' Medici]] || 1531 || 1532 || son of Lorenzo II de Medici, ruled in exile, returned and became Duke of Florence, where he was assassinated. |} ===[[House of Medici|Medici]] [[Duchy of Florence|dukes of Florence]], 1532–1569=== {| class="wikitable" |- ! Portrait !! Name !! From !! To !! Note |- | [[File:Jacopo Pontormo 056.jpg|75px]] || [[Alessandro de' Medici]] || 1532 || 1537 || son of Lorenzo II de Medici, ruled in exile, returned and became Duke of Florence, where he was assassinated. |- | [[File:Agnolo Bronzino - Cosimo I de' Medici in armour - Google Art Project.jpg|75px]] || [[Cosimo I de' Medici, Grand Duke of Tuscany|Cosimo I de' Medici]] || 1537 || 1569 || son of [[Giovanni dalle Bande Nere]], later became the first Grand Duke of Tuscany. |} ==Medici [[Grand Duchy of Tuscany|grand dukes of Tuscany]], 1569–1737== {| class="wikitable" |- ! Portrait !! Name !! From !! To !! Note |- | [[File:Agnolo Bronzino - Cosimo I de' Medici in armour - Google Art Project.jpg|75px]] || [[Cosimo I de' Medici, Grand Duke of Tuscany]] || 1569 || 1574 || son of [[Giovanni dalle Bande Nere]], maternal great-grandson of [[Lorenzo de' Medici|Lorenzo the Magnificent]]. |- | [[File:Francesco I de Medici.jpg|75px]] || [[Francesco I de' Medici]] || 1574 || 1587 || son of Cosimo I |- | [[File:Ferdinando i de' medici 12.JPG|75px]] || [[Ferdinando I de' Medici]] || 1587 || 1609 || son of Cosimo I |- | [[File:Cristofano Allori - Cosimo II (1608-1618).jpg|75px]] || [[Cosimo II de' Medici]] || 1609 || 1621 || son of Ferdinando I |- | [[File:Portrait Ferdinando II de Medici.jpg|75px]] || [[Ferdinando II de' Medici]] || 1621 || 1670 || son of Cosimo II |- | [[File:Grand Duke CosimoIII of Tuscany by van Douven.jpg|75px]] || [[Cosimo III de Medici|Cosimo III de' Medici]] || 1670 || 1723 || son of Ferdinando II |- | [[File:Giangastone de' Medici.jpg|75px]] || [[Gian Gastone de' Medici]] || 1723 || 1737 || son of Cosimo III, was the last Medici Grand Duke of Tuscany. |} ==[[Habsburg-Lorraine]] grand dukes of Tuscany, 1737–1801== {| class="wikitable |- ! Portrait !! Name !! From !! To !! Note |- | [[File:Workshop of Martin van Meytens Kaiser Franz Stephan 02.jpg|75px]] || [[Francis I, Holy Roman Emperor|Francesco II Stefano]] || 1737 || 1765 || a great-great-great-grandson of Francesco I, later became Holy Roman Emperor. |- | [[File:Mengs, Anton Raphael - Pietro Leopoldo d'Asburgo Lorena, granduca di Toscana - 1770 - Prado.jpg|75px]] || [[Leopold II, Holy Roman Emperor|Pietro Leopoldo I]] || 1765 || 1790 || second son of Francis I, also became Holy Roman Emperor. |- | [[File:Joseph Dorffmeister 002.jpg|75px]] || [[Ferdinand III, Grand Duke of Tuscany|Ferdinando III]] || 1790 || 1801 || second son of Leopold I |} ==[[House of Bourbon-Parma|Bourbon-Parma]] [[kings of Etruria]], 1801–1807== {| class="wikitable" cellpadding=2 cellspacing=2 |- !width=8%|Name!!width=6%|Portrait!!width=10%|Started!!width=10%|Ended!!width=30%|Relationship with predecessor(s) |- | [[Louis of Etruria|Lodovico I]] | [[File:Luis de Etruria.jpg|center|100px]] | 3 Aug 1801 | 27 May 1803 | Grandson of Francisco II Stefano |- | [[Charles II, Duke of Parma|Lodovico II]] | [[File:Carlo II di Parma.jpg|center|100px]] | 27 May 1803 | 10 Dec 1807 | son of Lodovico I |} ''Tuscany was annexed by France, 1807–1814. Napoleon's sister [[Elisa Bonaparte]] was given the honorary title of ''Grand Duchess of Tuscany'', but did not actually rule over the region.'' ==[[Habsburg-Lorraine]] grand dukes of Tuscany, 1814–1860== {| class="wikitable" cellpadding=2 cellspacing=2 |- ! Portrait !! Name !! From !! To !! Note |- | [[File:Joseph Dorffmeister 002.jpg|75px]] || [[Ferdinand III, Grand Duke of Tuscany|Ferdinando III]] || 1814 || 1824 || Restored |- | [[File:Leopold II of Tuscany.jpg|75px]] || [[Leopold II, Grand Duke of Tuscany|Leopoldo II]] || 1824 || 1859 || son of Ferdinando III |- | [[File:FerdinandTuscany.jpg|75px]] || [[Ferdinand IV, Grand Duke of Tuscany|Ferdinando IV]] || 1859 || 1860 || son of Leopoldo II |} ''Leopoldo II was driven from Tuscany by revolution from 21 February to 12 April 1849, and again on 27 April 1859. He abdicated in favor of his son, Ferdinando IV, on 21 July 1859, but Ferdinando IV was never recognized in Tuscany, and was deposed by the provisional government on 16 August. Tuscany was annexed by [[Kingdom of Sardinia|Piedmont-Sardinia]], on 22 March 1860.'' ==Titular Habsburg-Lorraine claimants, 1860–present== * [[Ferdinand IV, Grand Duke of Tuscany|Ferdinando IV]] 1860–1908 * [[Archduke Josef Ferdinand of Austria|Giuseppe Ferdinando]] 1908–1921 * [[Archduke Peter Ferdinand of Austria|Pietro Ferdinando]] 1921–1948 * [[Archduke Gottfried of Austria|Goffredo]] 1948–1984 * [[Archduke Leopold Franz of Austria|Leopoldo Francesco]] 1984–1993 * [[Archduke Sigismund of Austria (born 1966)|Sigismondo]] 1993–Present ==See also== * [[List of Tuscan consorts]] * [[Grand Duchy of Tuscany]] * [[History of Tuscany]] * [[Line of succession to the former Austro-Hungarian throne#Tuscany line]] {{Grand Dukes of Tuscany}} {{DEFAULTSORT:List Of Rulers Of Tuscany}} [[Category:Rulers of Florence| ]] [[Category:People from Tuscany]] [[Category:Dukes of Florence|*]] [[Category:Grand Dukes of Tuscany|*]] [[Category:Margraves of Tuscany|*]] [[Category:Lists of Italian people]] [[Category:Lists of European rulers|Tuscany]] [[Category:History of Tuscany]] [[Category:Grand Duchy of Tuscany]] [[Category:House of Habsburg-Lorraine]] [[Category:House of Medici]] [[Category:People of the Republic of Florence]] [[Category:Royal houses of the Grand Duchy of Tuscany]]
